snippet: Outraged Bolivian officials insisted American pressure was to blame for France and Portugal denying the Bolivian president’s plane access to their airspace amid a rumor that Edward J. Snowden was on board.
abstract: Offhand remark by Bolivian Pres Evo Morales while in Moscow that he might be happy to host Edward J Snowden escalates into political uproar when his plane is rerouted over suspicions that Snowden is on board; outraged Bolivian officials say American pressure is to blame for France and Portugal denying Morales’ plane access to their airspace.

byline.original: By RICK GLADSTONE and WILLIAM NEUMAN
byline.contributor: Rick Gladstone reported from New York, and William Neuman from Caracas, Venezuela. David M. Herszenhorn and Andrew Roth contributed reporting from Moscow, and Monica Machicao from La Paz, Bolivia.

lead_paragraph: Outraged Bolivian officials insisted American pressure was to blame for France and Portugal denying the Bolivian president’s plane access to their airspace amid a rumor that Edward J. Snowden was on board.

headline.main: New Rumor of Snowden Flight Raises Tensions
headline.print_headline: Snowden Drama Ensnares An Angry Bolivian Leader
